response.answer_text: Covanent, Since I’m not a fan of five line poems, I’ll pass on trying to determine my favorite. But I do have a five-line segment of a poem that I feel is one of the most magnificent that I’ve ever read. It’s from Thomas Gray’s magnificent “Elegy Written in a Country Churchyard.” (You know the old saying that if one has to guess the source of a popular expression or a book title or… then, it’s probably from the Bible or Shakespeare. Well, to perfectly cover the waterfront, we’d have to honestly also include Gray’s “Elegy” and Alexander Pope’s “Essay on Criticism.”) Gray wrote this very thoughtful work about 1750 or 1751. In it he addresses all the advantages that certain people have in life. He writes about these four groups: 1 - The royalty (or those of high position) 2 - The powerful 3 - The beautiful 4 -The wealthy. Covenant, you have to admit, those four groups certainly have great advantages in life. Well, Thomas Gray pretty much evens the score when he wrote: The boast of heraldry, The pomp of power, And all that beauty, all that wealth e’er gave, Await alike th’ inevitable hour… The paths of glory lead but to the grave. That evens the score, doesn’t it?
